newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexican stocks close down on profit-taking, Dow.
newsitem.headline: Mexican stocks close down on profit-taking, Dow.

text.p: Mexican stocks closed lower Tuesday in a session marked by profit-taking and a sluggish Dow Jones, traders said.

"The market was very weak, and it did follow the Dow today. There was heavy profit-taking. We think it will continue to adjust until it reaches the 3,250-point level," said Francisco Blanco, director of equity analysis at the Arka brokerage.
"We're in the consolidation period we needed for the bolsa to gather strength for a rally," he added.
The blue chip IPC index closed down 31.92 points, or 0.96 percent, at 3,309.27.
Volume was a mediocre 70.1 million shares traded. A total of 106 stocks changed hands, with losers outnumbering winners 52 to 29, while 25 were unchanged.
"Volume is still low, both domestic and foreign traders are staying on the sidelines," a floor trader said.
Prospects of interest rate cuts at Tuesday evening's primary auction did not seem to motivate stock traders, either, traders said.
Financial group GFInver ACP series headed the percentage leaders, gaining 10 centavos (1 cent) to 1.10 pesos (15 cents).

"There was speculative buying of that financial stock. There's talk again of an alliance with Santander, but that's been going on for a while. Let's see if something does happen this time," said a floor trader.

Holding company Accelsa A2 series led the winners' list for most of the session due, analysts said, to its favourable outlook for 1997 and what was felt to be a cheap share price. Accelsa A2 closed up 66 centavos (9 cents) up at 13.16 pesos ($1.74).
